processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/MS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/MS

passages.text: August 29, 2025 05:47 PM GMT

We initiate a long position in the 20- year breakeven, supported by compelling linker valuations across multiple metrics and a favourable supply calendar for the October- December period, which notably includes no long- linker auctions.

- The October-December gilt operations calendar signals a continued reduction in weighted-average maturity, particularly within the linker segment.- Heavy short-end supply may exert some pressure on valuations, but we expect demand for the sector to remain resilient.- We recommend fading the recent cheapening in long-end breakeven (long IL45 B/E) on no long-linker supply ahead and compelling valuations.- We also maintain our front-end long and steepening exposure, through receive Nov MPC and 3s10s gilt steepener.- Focus shifts to the upcoming 10y syndication; we have reviewed the sector performance preceding events and after syndications.
Please add me to your distribution list.

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

\(+ =\) Analysts employed by non- U.S. affiliates are not registered with FINRA, may not be associated persons of the member and may not be subject to FINRA restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst account.

The main focus of the past week was the release of the October- December 2025 gilt operations calendar (see Exhibit 1). While the calendar did not deviate substantially from the expectations set out in the August consultation minutes, it reinforced the ongoing reduction in the weighted- average maturity (WAM) of supply, with the burden clearly shifting toward the front end of the curve. Unsurprisingly, the immediate market reaction was a steepening in ASWs.
Exhibit 1: Oct-Nov gilt supply schedule

DateNameTypeSector01/10/2025IL 35Outright AuctionIL02/10/20254T 35Outright AuctionMedium07/10/2025Conventional giltTender08/10/2025New 29Outright AuctionShort14/10/202515y conventional syndication*SyndicationMedium15/10/2025IL 31Outright AuctionIL21/10/2025Green 53Outright AuctionLong23/10/2025New 31Outright AuctionShort28/10/2025IL 35Outright AuctionIL29/10/2025New 33Outright AuctionMedium30/10/2025Short conventional giltTenderShort04/11/2025New 29Outright AuctionShort05/11/2025Linker syndication*SyndicationIL11/11/2025Index-linked giltTenderIL12/11/20254T 35Outright AuctionMedium18/11/2025Conventional giltTender20/11/2025New 31Outright AuctionShort02/12/2025SR 56Outright AuctionLong03/12/2025New 29Outright AuctionShort04/12/2025Medium conventional giltTenderMedium09/12/2025IL 31Outright AuctionIL10/12/20254T 35Outright AuctionMedium16/12/2025New 31Outright AuctionShort
Source: UK DMO, Morgan Stanley Research,\\* Syndication dates are estimated

In the short sector, two new lines were announced: a 3- year (May- 29) and a 5- year (March 31), both issued via auction and consistent with strong GEMM and investor support. The emphasis on the front end was further underlined by a £7bn transfer from the unallocated bucket into the short conventional programme.

In the medium section, a new 7- year (Mar- 33) gilt was announced, a decision that received less export from both GEMMs and investors. Aside from this, there were few surprises. The new 2035 gilt, set to be syndicated next week, is scheduled for three reopenings, in line with consultation feedback. At the long end, issuance was also mostly as expected, focused on the green 2053 and the 2056 conventional gilt.

For linkers, the calendar concentrated issuance at shorter maturities, with multiple auctions in the IL 31 and IL 35, and a November syndication set for a new or existing indexed gilt, with the IL 38 being the most frequently highlighted candidate in the consultations.

Overall, the DMO has closely adhered to the guidance that emerged from the consultation process, particularly by leaning into the market's call for a shorter weighted- average maturity. The decision to cluster three new short- to medium- dated lines within a single quarter could place some pressure on front- end ASWs, driven by liquidity and NIP considerations.

Meanwhile, we think the lack of long- end linker supply should serve as a supportive catalyst for valuations. Linkers have continued to cheapen on various metrics, while historically elevated real yields have failed to attract meaningful investor demand (see Exhibit 2). Linkers have also recently underperformed nominals, as shown by the cheapening in beta- weighted breakevens (see Exhibit 3). This underperformance reflects broader weakness across the duration complex and subdued demand at the long end.
Exhibit 2: Real yields continued to trend higher...
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 3: ...while linkers underperformed nominals on a beta-weighted (70%) breakeven basis
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

The usual drivers remain in play such as ongoing fiscal and monetary policy uncertainty, which have kept investors cautious despite long- end real yields hovering around the 2.5% level. That said, we believe the complete lack of long- end linker supply should provide some support for valuations, after the relentless cheapening.
Next week, the DMO is scheduled to tap the 2045 linker on Monday, with a planned

notional size of £800 million (equivalent to roughly £1.1 million per basis point in DV01 terms). The sector has continued to cheapen on multiple valuation metrics (see Exhibit 4), underperforming the broader real yield complex.
Exhibit 4: IL 45 valuation metrics
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 5: IL 45 micro files
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

From a micro- valuation perspective, the 15- 20y sector has also cheapened, including the specific 2045 bond. As shown in Exhibit 5, the real yield and z- spread fly versus its immediate neighbours indicate a relative concession. This pricing dynamic, when combined with the absence of incremental long- end linker supply into next quarter, should act as a stabilising factor and provide support for demand at the upcoming auction.

Taking these considerations together, we suggest initiating a long breakeven position in the 2045 linker at 2.97%. We set an initial target of 3.20%, with a stop at 2.85% (reference bond: 4T 43). In our view, the combination of sector- level cheapening, bond- specific relative value, and constrained supply creates an attractive entry point, with asymmetry skewed to the upside. The key risk to the trade is a lack of demand for long- end linkers and a cheapening versus nominal.

Looking ahead, the key event next week will be the upcoming 10- year syndication, a new October 2035 maturity line with a 4.75% coupon. Building on our previous analysis of medium- dated syndications, we broaden the framework to examine sector performance rather than focusing solely on the syndicated line itself.

Our findings suggest a consistent pattern of cheapening into syndication, followed by average post- event richening (see Exhibit 6). The analysis of all previous 10y and 15y syndications is based on two- factor PCA residuals of par rates, computed using the three months of data preceding the event and selecting either the 10y or 15y maturity depending on the line being syndicated
In parallel, we looked at interpolated swap spreads around the maturity closest to the syndicated bond (10y or 15y). As shown in Exhibit 7, results appear somewhat
inconsistent: compared with the residual behaviour, swap spreads tend to tighten after syndication, indicating a cheapening of the syndicated sector versus swaps.
Exhibit 6: Two-Factor residuals of syndication par rate around the supply event
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 7: Interpolated gilt spreads (swap - par rate) around syndications
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

We maintain our 3s10s gilt steepener, supported by the macro and demand/supply backdrops. While the October- November supply calendar is somewhat less supportive for the front end, we believe demand remains solid in this sector. In addition, the recent hawkish repricing of BoE expectations should limit downside risks for front- end duration, while ongoing monetary and fiscal policy uncertainty is likely to underpin higher term premia and steeper curves, all else equal.

We also maintain our receive November MPC trade, which continues to look attractive from a risk/reward perspective. With around 5bp of cumulative cuts currently priced by November, the trade could deliver a \(\sim 20\) bp payout if the BoE were to cut at that meeting as per our economist forecasts.

As shown in our screener (see Exhibit 8), we note the recent richening of the green 33 line, perhaps supported by the lack of supply in the upcoming quarter. The current CTD (3T 38) has remained cheap, but it appears to have exerted some pressure on the 4T 38 line, which has also cheepened. The green 53s have recently cheepened, likely reflecting next quarter's supply expectations. Finally, the 61s have richened substantially over the past few weeks, while the 7Is have also remained on the rich side.
Exhibit 8: Gilts relative value monitor
Source: Morgan Stanley Research, All metrics are reported as 1m aggregate z-score.
·Trade idea: Enter long IL 4S Breakeven at 2.97%, target 3.20%, stop at 2.85% (reference bond: 4T 43)
·Trade idea: Maintain receive November MPC at 3.93%, target 3.83%,stop loss 3.98%
·Trade idea: Maintain 4R 28 vs. 4H 35 gilt steepener at 74.5bp, target 90bp, stop loss 60bp
·Trade idea: Maintain long ONZ5 96.60/96.80/97.00/97.20 call condor
Exhibit 9: Swap spread levels and weekly changes
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 10: Model residuals and weekly changes
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Below you will find a list of our current trade ideas, entry levels, entry dates, rationales,and risks.

Buy/Long: The analyst expects the total or excess return (depending on the nature of the recommendation) of the instrument or issuer that is the subject of the investment recommendation to be positive over the relevant time period.

Sell/Short: The analyst expects the total or excess return (depending on the nature of the recommendation) of the instrument or issuer that is the subject of the investment recommendation to be negative over the relevant time period.
Selling protection or Buying Risk: The analyst expects that the price of protection against the event occurring will decrease over the relevant time period.
Buying protection or Selling Risk: The analyst expects the price of protection against the event occurring will increase over the relevant time period.
Pay: The analyst expects that over the specified time period the variable rate underlying the swap agreement that is the subject of the investment recommendation will increase.
Receive: The analyst expects that over the specified time period the variable rate underlying the swap agreement that is the subject of the investment recommendation will decrease.

Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for recommendations included in the Morgan Stanley Fixed Income Research reports is 1- 3 months and the price of financial instruments mentioned in the recommendation is as at the date and time of publication of the recommendation.

When more than one issuer or instrument is included in a recommendation, analyst expects one part of the trade to outperform the other trade or combination of other trades included in the recommendation on a relative basis.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

A distribution of the different MS Research ratings or recommendations, in percentage terms for Investments in each sector covered, is available upon request from your sales representative.

The information in Morgan Stanley Research is being communicated by Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc (QFC Branch), regulated by the Qatar Financial Centre Regulatory Authority (the QFCRA), and is directed at business customers and market counterparties only and is not intended for Retail Customers as defined by the QFCRA.

As required by the Capital Markets Board of Turkey, investment information, comments and recommendations stated here, are not within the scope of investment advisory activity. Investment advisory service is provided exclusively to persons based on their risk and income preferences by the authorized firms. Comments and recommendations stated here are general in nature. These opinions may not fit to your financial status, risk and return preferences. For this reason, to make an investment decision by relying solely to this information stated here may not bring about outcomes that fit your expectations.

The trademarks and service marks contained in Morgan Stanley Research are the property of their respective owners. The Global Industry Classification Standard (GICS) was developed by and is the exclusive property of MSCI and S&P.

Morgan Stanley Research, or any portion thereof may not be reprinted, sold or redistributed without the written consent of Morgan Stanley. Indicators and trackers referenced in Morgan Stanley Research may not be used as, or treated as, a benchmark under Regulation EU 2016/1011, or any other similar framework. The issuers and/or fixed income products recommended or discussed in certain fixed income research reports may not be continuously followed. Accordingly, investors should regard those fixed income research reports as providing stand- alone analysis and should not expect continuing analysis or additional reports relating to such issuers and/or individual fixed income products. Morgan Stanley may hold, from time to time, material financial and commercial interests regarding the company subject to the Research report.

Registration granted by SEBI and certification from the National Institute of Securities Markets (NISM) in no way guarantee performance of the intermediary or provide any assurance of returns to investors.
